Shanghai, China.
Nov. 6, 1938
Dearest Kits:
So much to say I hardly know where to start.
I left Nanking Wednesday at
six in a hire car with two Chinese passengers and one other foreign passenger and
two
Chinese chauffeurs,
each one nearly as big as Chillie Vaughn.
It took us thirteen
and one
half
nour's
to
you
would not have
make Shanghai.
It was
intensely interesting but I am sure
The road was narrow
all
the
way
way,
rainy
liked it, until you had got to Shanghai.
and
misty most of the way.
The road was fairly good some of the
but muddy
and rutty most of the way.
and were very
nice.
We
The two Chinese passengers spoke English
were stopped many
times by soldiers and
questioned but never
delayed.
that
We took a road running south of Wusith on the south side of Tahu Lake
comes in to the Shanghai Hangehow road about two or three miles from Minghongâ€¢
Of course all of such trips have asbad
reputation and Mr. Johnson will
not give
authority for
any
one
TO
make it.
We skidded badly on one place where the road is
narrow and on
top
of a
dyke about fifteen feet high and I thought we were
over surely.
We were,
but fortunately the side of the car smashed into a
going
and held us.
tree
The
side of the car was badly smashed, glass broken,
but fortunately
it was shatter proof,
the door was jammed, fender
smashed and top
of car bent in,
but we didn't go over, and the frame of the chassis wasn't bent.
We all got out,
got the
car back in the road.
I found out why the two big Chinese chauffeurs were
used, and we went on.
We had to run in low and second so
much we boiled out most
of the water in the radiator and the engine got so hot it ran for five minutes with
the switch
off.
Finally stopped it by putting it in high gear with the brakes on.
We didn't have anything to get water in, dark as hell, but the car had one of the
old style
horns with a big rubber bulb about as big as your head so the chauffeur
took it off and sucked up water in it from a wayside ditch and squirted in the
radiator,
You can't beat the Chinese.
We got stuck several
times but managed to
push ourselves out.
We struck
the ferry west of Minghong about five A.M. at daybreak.
ferry
came over,
The
unloaded two new truck chassis and then turned around and went
back empty.
We inquired as to what in the hell was going on and were told that
there were about thirty
trucks on the other side going to lanking and the drivers
had parked their trucks all over the road on the other side and dow both the loading
and unloading runways so that it was impossible to unload anything
on the other
side.
Can you imagine anything more typical than that, more unbelievable?
I immediately
decided that
was no place for us.
We were only about fifteen miles or less from
the Front and if the weather that day was good all those new trucks standing there
would draw Jay planes like sugar drawing flies.
It took 35 minutes to make a round
trip on the ferry taking two trucks at a time and we were in for an eight hour wait.
I got our other
passengers together and told them I thought we should cross outselves
on the instishxferax empty ferry going back and wait on the other side for our car
to get over.
There was no place to flop, no where to go, no protection at all and
in case of attack it would have been a death trap.
The other foreigner agreed at
once but the Chinese said the other side was like this side and we might logse our
baggage.
I told him I thought it was important to get over before flying started
and not get caught on the ferry, and once on the other side we could walk down the
